statement:
Ler $R$ be of a commutative ring with nonzero unity. If
$$\begin{aligned}
\mathfrak{a} \;=\; (a_1,\,\ldots,\,a_m) \;=\; (\alpha_1,\,\ldots,\,\alpha_\mu)\end{aligned}$$
and $$\begin{aligned}
\mathfrak{b} \;=\; (b_1,\,\ldots,\,b_n) \;=\, (\beta_1,\,\ldots,\,\beta_\nu)\end{aligned}$$
are two finitely generated ideals of $R$, both with two , then the
ideals
$$\mathfrak{c} \;:=\; (a_1b_1,\,\ldots,\,a_ib_j,\,\ldots,\,a_mb_n)$$ and
$$\mathfrak{d} \;:=\; (\alpha_1\beta_1,\,\ldots,\,\alpha_i\beta_j,\,\ldots,\,\alpha_\mu\beta_\nu)$$
are equal.\
*Proof.* By (1) and (2), for every $i,\,j$, there are elements
$r_{ik},\,s_{jl}$ of $R$ such that $$\begin{aligned}
a_i \;=\; r_{i1}\alpha_1\!+\ldots+r_{i\mu}\alpha_\mu, \quad b_j \;=\; s_{j1}\beta_1\!+\ldots+s_{j\nu}\beta_\nu.\end{aligned}$$
Multiplying the equations (3) we see that $$a_ib_j \;=\; 
(r_{i1}s_{j1})(\alpha_1\beta_1)\!+\!(r_{i2}s_{j1})(\alpha_2\beta_1)\!+\ldots+\!(r_{i\mu}s_{j\nu})(\alpha_\mu\beta_\nu),$$
whence the generators $a_ib_j$ of $\mathfrak{c}$ belong to
$\mathfrak{d}$ and consecuently $\mathfrak{c} \subseteq \mathfrak{d}$.
The reverse containment is seen similarly.
names: well-definedness of product of finitely generated ideals
